hi bill. when making music, making ideas and stuff comes easy but when I try to revise them I just never get it done. my teacher and my parents push me to revise my works, but it's hard to find motivation. any thoughts?
(btw you're amazing)

the risk in 'revising' is that it might make it worse and less genuine. The benefit, however, is that it might make it more coherent. I spent a long time being unable or afraid to do this. i just kept writing new things. but eventually i just got so jealous of 'normal' songs, for having a repeating chorus, etc, that i figured it out. Half of the struggle, i think, is just choosing which item you're going to work on. for me it was necessary to first gather all the items into a list. Then i would go through the list one at a time, and make a few moves on each one. the 'diagnosis' is important. Play through the existing material, get a first impression, see if you generally like it or if it sucks, .... then start diagnosing it. If it's a small idea, figure out if it's the beginning or not the beginning. If it's already a long / complete idea, just go through from the beginning and find the first place where it truly sucks or is not good enough. This point is what i call the 'split point', the point where the existing material stops being good enough. So you put the rest aside, and write from there. I generally don't think it's good to plan on writing to connect to what comes after -- very risky and strange to do this. But it might happen automatically. so you can be open to that, but, plan on just writing from the split point and doing what's truly right from the split point

how did you highlight the globe for hotewig? on a 2d map, you mask the section and change the hue. in order to project the map onto the globe, do you need to do a UV mapping?

the best way i found, was to export 2 versions of the same 3D clip. First you have to make an alternate map. Take the world map you're using (probably an equirectangular, 1 by 2 rectangle), and make a second map, with everything blacked out except your desired region. Then, swap in that map to the globe, then re-render the exact same clip, with the exact same camera movement, in the exact same time range. Then, when you import those clips to your 2D program, put the region/black map on top. then key out the black. then fuck the colors as desired

I feel i should probably stop telling everyone to "write" a lot, because maybe some people just don't enjoy witing. But .... for you, it seems like you are perfectly comfartable writing, as you've just demonstrated. So i think you should find your most comfortable writing tool (a text editor on a computer, wherever you are most comfortable writing/typing), and just start.... USING it. Do anything you can in it. Use it to be honest. Use it to paint pictures. i don't care what you use it for, .... anywhere between honesty and art, fiction to diagrams, .... i mean, just test the keyboard, to start out with. Make sure every key is working. This will be one of the simplest ways to get your brain to start putting things into the world. Basically what we need to do is open up these pathways so your brain can start communicating with the world and putting things out there. you've demonstrated clearly that you are in the sort of 'consuming' stage, with some pent up desire to be the one on the other end of that. Maybe watch some film directors interviews on youtube. That could be a starting place. You might not want to direct films, but it might remind you of something else you do want to do. But another thing i should remind you, finding these things is like a river. You just make your best guess and do a thing, and then along the way you will hear some signals that will give you another hint of what you should try next. Trust me, these rivers ALWAYS get to huge dank oceans, eventually, if you let them flow. And you have made it clear that you have a huge amount of water to start with

Hi Bill, I've been writing a song, and I got to a point where I think there should be a chorus next, but I have no idea how I should continue the song into one. How do I write a chorus from what I've already written?

coming up with these things is like lightning striking. You can't really guarantee that it happens, but, i can tell you everything i know so far about this. 
1. it's most likely to happen when you run through the song, from the beginning, at the right tempo, without stopping
2. it gets more and more likely for it to happen the longer time it's been since you've heard the song. 
3. this is unfortunate, because it's very time consuming to keep waiting until you haven't heard the song in a while, every time you hear it
4. try walking to the door of the room you are in, touching the door handle, and then returning to the instrument (or demo-recording you are working with) and do a run through. this may be an artificial way to help 'reset' if you don't have time to wait 
5. if you're just not getting it, try to make categories of things, and try to rule them out.
6. for example, try continuing it to be the same as what came before. Hopefully you will get a strong signal "yes" or "no" from trying this. then you can rule that out, or in
7. try going to the most normal chord you haven't used yet. for example, if your verse is full of C and F chords, try G and see what happens
8. try something with dense melody/lyric (wordy). hopefully that will give you a strong 'yes' or 'no' signal
9. try something with very few words. see if you can rule that out or in
10. keep trying to categorically prove or dis-prove that a certain strategy is right or wrong
11. i forgot the most important thing which i should have said first, imagine a scene where your song takes place. then name something that could happen next. i should have mentioned this one first because it's probably the one that's most likely to work

how to build a chair?

Remove all parts from the carton and separate them into part number groups as indicated in the parts list.   To begin assembly, place the 5-star base   upside down and insert casters  into the bottom of base.   Turn the base   right side up on the floor and insert the cylinder  into the center hole on the base. Place the telescoping cover  over the the cylinder  and rest it on the base.   Attach the seat plate  to the bottom of the seat cushion (with front of seat plate facing the front of the  seat cushion) by using 15/8" screws  into the front holes of the seat plate  and 7/8" screws  into the  rear holes of the seat plate and tighten the screws.   Align the back cushion  with the seat cushion  by positioning the back support plate  over the seat  plate with 11/4" screws. Do not tighten the screws completely.   Attach the arms  respectively on each side onto the bottom of the seat cushion  and the sides  of back cushion  by using 11/2" screws. Tighten all the screws. Remember to tighten the screws on the  back support plate.   Place the plastic caps  into the two arm holes on each arm.   Place the assembled chair on top of the cylinder and press down until fully engaged.   Periodically (every 90 days) make sure that the screws are still fully tightened.

I have lots of ideas that I've recorded but I'm not really sure how to put them together.

if they weren't written together, then they probably are not part of the same song. i think if you try to put them together they may look like awkward surgery. So, pick 1, and then 'play doctor' with it. give it a diagnosis. Is it the beginning of the song? is it not the beginning of the song? is it a 'chorus'? is it not a chorus? What does this idea mean to you? try to remember everything about the circumstances of coming up with it. This should lead you to your next decision about what it needs. Another thing that i should mention about the way i do it, i always write the entire song all the way through before even touching the production process. I know that not everyone does it this way, but, i've found out, to play to my strengths it's important to remain as nimble as possible during the writing process, and that means not trying to actually produce it while writing. i am a 'write first' person, then produce what i wrote. Also another thing i should mention, i was in your situation (wanting to produce entire songs myself) and i knew i was qualified, because i had already been playing multiple instruments for at least 10 or 15 years before, so i thought it should be easy. but unfortunately it took me at least 10 MORE years after that before i really felt like i could comfortably get the entire job done. actually i'm still not really there yet. But who knows ..... maybe you will find a way to make things.... simpler

Makes perfect sense, but is also completely ridiculous. so the next line "the rumors start to go round the world that i'm crazy" well of course, because you're licking the moon. but no, instead, it's "becaususe you can't taste the cheese". so the fun score, for me, continues to be upheld up to that point. Next stanza, start with a line to echo the same theme as the first. famous phrase ('the grass is always green') then change it ('but i just changed it'). i think one of the things that's so compelling and satisfying about your music video style, and your musical style for that matter, re-watching 'here comes the sun' for the 15th time or whatever, is how understated a lot of things are, but also how overt and flashy certain things are. like, you'll have little moments that i don't even think about after several viewings, but then i see and i'm like, that's such a nice little moment, a little clip in the background of you doing a little finger wave with your hand or a little random stick figure guy climbing for a second or whatever. that's part of what's so incredible about your style is you have a very acute sense of how to keep things moving, not lingering too long on something, almost cutting things off before they have a chance to be boring, but just long enough to have an impact. it's very scintillating, if i'm allowed to use that word. anyways i hope your new music video is going well and you're  doing go od in general. you're one of the most inspiring modern musicians/artists to me and it's really humbling and exciting to be alive at the same time as you. i wish you all the success and happiness that you can handle.
